OTHER. A BLOODBATH ENSUES. ONE ALUMNI SHOOTS HER OWN HEAD
OFF, ANOTHER MOWS DOWN THE BAR, ETC.
SIZES AND OPEN FIRE ON MARTIN. THE UNITED FORCE INSTANTLY

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: VARIOUS EXTRA CLOSE-UPS of this luxurious patchwork of  brilliant greens:

dialogues.speaker: A POLISHED BRASS SPRINKLER HEAD
dialogues.text: pops up from the ground and begins to water the already d soaked lawn.

dialogues.speaker: FLEET OF DUCKLINGS
dialogues.text: No mother in sight, cruise through the thrushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bottom of a water hazard.

dialogues.speaker: PALM FRONDS
dialogues.text: After a neat they sway, revealing the barren desert that  surrounds the artificial oasis. The sun already bakes the air. We hear the opening guitar strains of the Kim Deal-K Cobain suet of "WHAT I DID FOR LOVE," as we CRANE DOWN th palms to A BRAND-NEW TITLEIST 3 BALL. Just on the edge of the rough. A pair of yellow trousers  moves in. An iron confidently addresses the ball, and chi it out. The trousers walk out after it.

dialogues.speaker: HANDS
dialogues.text: Digging dirt out of the grooves of the iron's face with a golf tee, while on the way to the green. Both hands are  gloved, instead of one, and the gloves are black.

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW TROUSERS
dialogues.text: In a squat over the ball, sizing up the curvy, fifty-foot journey to the hole. The figure positions himself and the putter above the ball, then pops the ball lightly. The ba rolls and bobs with purpose toward the hole, dodging haza and finding lanes, until it finally falls off of the gree and into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: THE GLOVED HAND
dialogues.text: Sets the ball on the next tee. The figure moves to a leat golf bag. The hands pull the wipe rag off of the top of t bag and drop it on the ground, reach into the bag, drawin out a compact SNIPER RIFLE, affixed with a long silencer. The figure drops one knee down onto the rag, the other fo firmly setting its spikes. We move the figure to see the  face of the sniper, concentrating down the scope in his h squat. He is MARTIN BLANK. We SWING AROUND behind his head to look down the barrel w him. Four-hundred yards away, on another part of the cour another green is barely visible through groves of trees a rough. Three miniscule, SILVER-HAIRED FIGURES come into v One of them, in a RED SWEATER sets up for first putt. He  could be an investment banker, or an arms trader.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S ARM
dialogues.text: Flinches, and a low THUNK reports from the rifle. A secon later in the distance, the

dialogues.speaker: RED SWEATER'S HEAD
dialogues.text: Seems to vanish from his shoulders into a crimson mist. H body crumples to the green.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Returns the rifle to the bag, pulls out a driver, moves t the tee and whacks the ball. He watches its path and whis absently...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outdoor post-golf luncheon area of an elite Texas gol club. Martin sits in on the fringes of a conversation bet a group of executive types. CLUB MEMBER #1 has a Buddha-l peace in his eyes through the philosophical talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd come to the realization that  everything I'd based my life on was  false. And that my life had no  meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Martin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets this way when he hits over  eighty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seemed like my life was slipping  away, somehow. I was a knot in the  middle of a wet rope. Everything was  futile and nothing had value.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way life is. The only  meaning and value is what we create.  Through structure, and discipline.  Though they seem to limit our freedom,  they actually give us great comfort.  Your problem is you're looking for  some great answer. Some ultimate  truth. When what you really should  do is go to work and go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And take golf lessons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a tragedy. Can I finish my  story please? I began my search for  meaning. I was a Catholic, Jew,  Scientologist, Sufi, Buddhist. I  went to a Psychologist, psychiatrist,  herbalist, nutritionist, a shaman,  and a psychic. And they all pretty  much say the same stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Jew, a shaman, and a herbalist are  telling you the same thing? You're  insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basically the same thing. In a very  evolved, esoteric way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To make a long story short...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Thank God--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...at last I found the holistic system  of systems that opened up the doors  of heaven for me right here on earth.  And everyday I see the world through  the eyes of a child. A world of  creation and wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overflowing with love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. Club Member #1 turns to Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.P.P. Personal Pan Power. All the  secrets of your universe are divided  up into eight easily digestible  slices. Club Member #1 pulls a laminated card from his wallet and hands it over to Martin. In the distance, sirens begin to wail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, see. It's in the accessible and  everyday shape of a pan pizza. Each  day you have a little slice of  peace...

dialogues.speaker: WALLET-SIZE P.P.P. CARD
dialogues.text: A pizza-shaped diagram showing six "sections".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I see. You got your individual  slices of hope, dignity, confidence,  self-love, justice, and harmony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You open 'em up and there's the  sayings, stories, little bites of  insight. It's the P.P.P. Six Day  Week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you eat-- read it everyday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And these pan pizzas have opened up  the doors to heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct. (re: the card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for you. Keep it. Sirens are getting louder, closer to the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The source of the sirens are almost upon us. Martin walks toward his rented Town Car as the VALET pulls it up. He m the Valet by the trunk, where he trades tip for keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fishes out the laminated "Personal  Pan Power" card, looks at it, and  tosses it onto the ground. Police  cars, now visible in the distance,  wind into the long club driveway.  Martin gets into his car and pulls  away.

dialogues.speaker: LAMINATED CARD
dialogues.text: As it lays on the asphalt. The wheel of a police car roll to a stop on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin sits in a first class seat, the tray table flipped down. On the left side of the tray is a stack of magazine of all kinds - Sports Illustrated, Mademoiselle, Wired,  Rolling Stone, National Review, Spin, National Geographic and on. He draws one off the top, and flips through it,  impassively taking in images and reading nothing. When he done with one, he discards it into the empty seat next to him and draws another-- Martin's way of instantly and  massively uploading the world around him: Toothless hockey player in triumph, Sony product parade,  crouched starving child with vulture in the background,  supermodel in suede, Tic Tacs, living former Presidents, in arm, smiling, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The livery weaves out of the arrival lanes at Kennedy air Martin reclines in the back seat, a conversation having  already begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was your day, today, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Effective. But to tell you the truth,  I've lost my passion for work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like the people you work with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it then. That's it. I've always  been alone. That's why I'm a good  driver. I can handle it. See, I can  think on my feet. I survive, I'm a  thinker. And I can sit there in front  of your house for two hours and it  don't bother me. Some people can't  do it! Some people are ranting and  raving, "Tell them fuckin' people to  get out here and get in this car, I  can't-- I want a go!" Where you gonna  go? You're gonna wind up back in  your garage at seven o'clock at night.  You ain't going nowhere. You leave  your house in the morning you get  back to your house in the evening.  What's the big deal, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand the psychology of the  job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. Some guys can't adjust to it;  they can't handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car cuts through the upper east side. Martin and the  Driver exchange looks through the rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like you're far away. Far  away and thinking about other things.  I'm right about that, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's just say that sometimes  I'm right. Sometimes you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I am. Sometimes. It's only  natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs to himself at  this great truth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only natural.... The Driver pauses for dramatic emphasis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been looking at you, and I've  decided that I want to share something  with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because your problem is you're bored.  And you have a very big mind. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am part of what I call a brain  syndicate. No reaction from Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am part of a network of minds, a  group of five people who are all  connected, over hundreds, even  thousands of miles, through the mind.  We can think with each other, think  for each other. I can be driving  somewhere, sleeping with a woman--  whatever it is-- and at the same  time be thinking a thought in someone  else's mind, far away. Running someone  else's brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up on the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when you think of it, it's not  so surprising that a small group of  people control the whole world, is  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sedate and well-appointed four-star suite on the Upper  East Side. Martin stands in front of one of the open wind watching the canopied entrance of an elegant high-rise ac the street. He lifts an eye rinse cup to his eye and tilt it back. A cellular phone RINGS, interrupting him. He mov to the desk and draws one of three phones from his briefc depresses a scrambler module, flips it open, and listens a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's not there, I can't proceed.  Tell them. Martin hangs up. Picks up another phone and dials. As he  waits for an answer, he goes to a Fed Ex blueprint tube l on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom. I've been waiting for an answer.  I'm only in town tonight. He breaks the shipping seal and pulls out a series of fin metal parts including a long thin barrel, a scope, and a  silencer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's different this time than the  last time? I have to be down front...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stands in front of the window, phone in one hand, scope in the other. Next to him, the assembled rifle rest across the arm of a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't bother to call anyone  else because you always take care of  me. He glances over to a second window to his left, which off a view further down the street. He goes to it. He raises scope and sees

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few blocks down, small even through the high-powered sc is your average BICYCLE MESSENGER dressed in lycra racing gear, weaving through traffic toward us. Slung low across his right hip is a black canvas bag. The Messenger's hand hidden in it. The other phone begins to RING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on a second, Tom. I got my hands  full here. He sets down the phone and answers the other, still watch the messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Account number 3649367, transfer  to account number 96-546-38739-47825.  Ask for Mr. Sanchez, tell him it's  Mr. Duckman. If there are any  problems, access file 673594638-IO- 98, and look at it. Martin drops the phone and moves away from Window #2 to t rifle. He mounts the scope and he looks out Window #1 at high-rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of a DOORMAN opening the door for a group of five men in  suits. Four BODYGUARDS form a perimeter around the fifth  man, a mall, avuncular figure in his forties dressed in  Saville Row finery.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Takes a step back into the shadows of the room, and raise the rifle toward Window #2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of an empty street. The bicycle messenger flashes past.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: concentrating, tracks the path of the Messenger, leading left to right across the blind spot of the hotel room wal between Window #2 and Window #1.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: the bicycle Messenger bears down on the group of men, dra a Mac-10 submachine gun from his bag. The group see him-- just as Martin's sniper FIRE explodes the Messenger's che Two of the Bodyguards collapse onto their boss. The other two open fire on the Messenger as he wipes out horribly i a parked car in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: withdraws from the window, and picks up the phone again a begins to break down the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry Tom. But look, I know it's the  playoffs. That's why I'm offering a  thousand dollars for one seat... Martin listens patiently as he works.

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN'S HANDS
dialogues.text: unbuttoning his double-breasted long coat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: just finishes packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well let me ask you, Tom. What do  I have to do to get courtside tickets  for the Knicks...?

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: The two bodyguards kick at the Messenger's body. The othe two begin to move off of their boss, who rises cowering. Doorman stands behind it all, unbuttoning his coat.

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN
dialogues.text: a tall, dark, sharp-featured man in his forties, wearing handlebar moustache. He moves toward the group of men as flips open his coat back over two huge chrome .44 Magnum  Charthouse Bulldog revolvers and OPENS FIRE on them.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: is closing his bag when he hears the gun-thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. I gotta go. Martin drops the phone, grabs his scope, and spins to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the Doorman kicking through the pile of dead bodyguard He gets to the man at the bottom-- their boss. The Doorma FIRES both guns.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: reacts, surprised to see a second shooter. He pulls himse from the window, puts away his scope, and accelerates his exit.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH-RISE FOYER
dialogues.text: Outside, we see the doorman drop both guns on the pile of bodies. He walks back toward us through the glass doors a makes his way through the building toward the service exi He sheds his uniform and stuffs it into a plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: his two parcels in hand, exits out the side door of the h and walks down the street.

dialogues.speaker: DOORMAN
dialogues.text: now wearing rich man's sweats, hops off the loading dock, walks to a Lincoln Town Car, and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin rolls down FDR Drive in a Lincoln Town Car once ag on the cellular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Tell them that's not my problem.  I was paid for one job-- the cyclist--  not two. See you tomorrow, Marcella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. I have Mr. Grocer for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patch him through.... Martin notices another Town Car appears in the next lane. recognize the Doorman behind the wheel, phone in hand. He GROCER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm setting up a concern that would  enable those of us in our rarefied  profession to consolidate our efforts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a union?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a club. Work less, make more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could be working together, making  big money, killing important people...  I'm willing to let you in on the  ground floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you could be... sort of like...  a father figure to me.... Grocer ignores this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a free-market evolution. You'll  wake up to it... c'mon Kid. We used  to run together when you were a  rookie. I don't want to run against  you. This thing's real. Everybody's  in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me. So don't paw at me with your  dirty little guild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get you, kid. Martin hangs up and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin sits in first class, wiping his face and hands wit an airline hot towel. He folds the wet cloth and once aga speeds through the images from a thick stack of magazines He looks up as he hears PILOT V.O.  It's seventy-six degr and partly cloudy in Chicago this afternoon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin walks into a sparsely furnished apartment. He wear drops his carry-on bag and briefcase in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin sits on a futon couch watching MTV with no sound. the coffee table in front of him is a phalanx of vitamin  bottles. Martin takes some capsules from each and washes  them down with a reddish-orange beverage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin lies on his back on the hardwood floor. His eyes a closed and he wears a set of headphones as he absently ta his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear Alumni: Can you believe it's  been ten years? Where are you now...? After a moment, his eyes open, alerted. His head turns to the side, and his hands lightly cup the headphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from the headphones as it winds to a small metal box, wit one unmarked switch and one amber light- definitely not a walkman. The wire continues out of the other side of the  box, across the floor, connecting to a suction cup stuck the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Are you guiding an Outward Bound  canoe trip like Brook Stinson? Or  perhaps in charge of appearances for  the NFL like Leslie Gunther....?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: draws a pre-cut section of the floor, the width of a penc and twice as long, by a string.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO MONITOR
dialogues.text: The greenish Starlight (night vision) image of a young, H MAN sleeping on his back, as seen from above. A fine thre snakes from behind CAMERA to just above the man's slack m We PULL BACK to reveal a Sony Watchman that holds the IMA KEEP PULLING to reveal Martin watching it as he maneuvers the thread down past the fiber-optic cable through the ho in the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: concentrates as he applies three drops of blue liquid on thread. As the drops run down along the thread through th floor, his attention shifts to the

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO MONITOR
dialogues.text: The drops, huge in the foreground, become smaller as they make their way down the line toward the sleeping man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Could it be that you're like Chip  Longfellow, at the trade-relations  tank in Washington. Sandy Glasser  owns a cheese shop...!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: adjusts the thread minutely with one hand, and lowers the fiber-optic cable with the other.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO MONITOR
dialogues.text: The face begins to fill the screen as the fiber-optic fol the drops toward it. Suddenly, the man snorts and turns h face...

dialogues.speaker: A DROP FALLS
dialogues.text: It misses the man's mouth and hit's his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO MONITOR
dialogues.text: The man's eyes snap open in terror as he looks directly i CAMERA. His image falls away as the fiber-optic is jerked back up through the hole in the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Looking at yearbooks and pictures  evokes so many memories...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hushed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: stuffs the apparati into an open duffel bag, and flies ou of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Some good. Some bad. But all  interesting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BODYGUARD sits outside an apartment door. A muffled but dire scream is heard from within and he is on his feet, g in hand. An exit door in the hallway slams open revealing Martin, his gun already pointed at the Bodyguard. The  Bodyguard levels his at Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freeze! Police! The Bodyguard hesitates just long enough to get double-ta through the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...As a graduate of the class of  1984, you are someone special... Martin moves to the dead Bodyguard, and locates a retract key chain on his belt. He unreels the ring of keys and op the door. He lets the keys retract back to the belt and d him into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin moves silently down the hall in a crouch. He comes the bedroom and slips across the threshold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Whenever news of you filters back,  the school is excited and proud of  your accomplishments...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin crouches down outside the bedroom door. He points gun at the door, and reaching up turns the knob. As the d opens, the Husky Man FIRES wildly over Martin's head. Mar returns with one shot to the hut which sits the man down the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We hope Grosse Pointe High prepared  you well to lead the kind of life  that makes an impact on the world... Martin kicks the gun away from the fallen man, and raises his barrel to the man's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Remember, "there's no where you  can go that you haven't learned how  to go in time... It's easy..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in severe pain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it is that I'm doing that  you don't like I'll stop doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not me. Martin cocks the gun....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The perpetual sun shines down on a small lot of pre-fab o bungalows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small suite of dry-walled offices.

dialogues.speaker: EAST-WEST HOLDING COMPANY
dialogues.text: is stenciled on glass doors behind Martin who stands in f of a young woman reading from some kind of invitation. Sh is MARCELLA MAYES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So come on back to the old oak  tree, acorns. Signed, the reunion  committee." Marcella holds up the mauve envelope and smiles slyly. Fo the first time, Martin looks scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw that away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tease me. You know what I do  for a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from one of those P.O. Boxes.  How was the trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tedious. I now authorize you to throw  away all personal mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And not show it to me. Ever again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's going to cost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay. Martin begins to walk past her into his office, but Marce stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not happy, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say their friend was suppose to  have a heart attack and die in his  sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They blame you for the compromise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they want me to make up for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Detroit. This weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them that's impossible. I need  my normal lead time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were very upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you describe their position as  inflexible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intractable, sir. You leave tonight. Marcella looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sir, I also get that broken- mirror, black-cat, Friday-the- thirteenth kind of feeling about  this one....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to be done about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I liquidated the last account in  Zurich, and split it into two new  ones in Estonia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. What else? Anything interesting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm, not really. But you're gonna  love this one. She hands him a piece of paper. He scans it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's a Greenpeace boat. It'd be  so easy. Martin looks at her wearily. He puts it into the paper  shredder at the side of her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have scruples. Next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paperwork on the Detroit thing. It's  a full dossier. Very comprehensive. She raises a thick brown dossier from the top of her desk and puts it down again. Martin moves through a door to hi private office.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Martin goes into his office and sits at his desk. On the  walls are a couple of boring prints of tallships. A books holds trappings of a loose attempt at a cover-- a few shi manifests, sealane tables, and other specialized referenc books on import/export. He sits and stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time has passed, and Martin still sits at his desk massag his gums with a rubber-tipped dental pointer.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. MARTIN'S TEETH
dialogues.text: The dental tool jumps across the gaps between his teeth l a hummingbird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should get going....

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: pulls back his jacket lapel and fits the utensil into a p protector that is also home to a toothbrush, emery board, tweezers, and comb. He stands and walks out of his office

dialogues.speaker: FOYER
dialogues.text: Martin moves toward the door. As he passes Marcella she h him the mauve envelope and a travel portfolio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget your identity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you next week. Martin stops short as he reaches the threshold. He holds the envelope, and stares a dagger through it. On his way  out, over his shoulder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Dr. Oatman I'm on my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin slouches on a leather couch. He holds the mauve  envelope, now open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you want to go to your  high school reunion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in Michigan. Honestly, what do  I have in common with those people?  Or with anyone? DR. OATMAN sits in the window. He is Kris Kringle-esque, wears a sheepskin vest, rough-hewn shirt, faded Levis, an old Frye boots. Oatman nods with the suave understanding a man happy to collect fifty thousand in fees before aski a tough question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went to school with these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've spent a lot of time discussing  those years. Remember we said that  fear is a transfer of the bodily  hurt associated by experience with  the thing feared, to the thought of  the thing. Thus we fear a dog without  distinctly imagining its bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you be taking notes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about your vision of the  reunion.

dialogues.speaker: FROM ABOVE
dialogues.text: Of a crowded gymnasium. The alumni below stops what they doing and look up at Martin, DRAWING GUNS OF ALL SHAPES A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be depressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll have husbands and wives and  children and houses and dogs....  made themselves a part of something.  And they can talk about what they  do. What am I going to say? (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I killed the President of Paraguay  with a fork." Oatman twitches nervously, almost spilling his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needn't be so frank with me about  your work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not. I trust you. You couldn't  turn me in because of Doctor-Patient  privilege... and I don't want to be  "withholding"... and I know where  you live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where I live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're both professionals, Oatman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think what you fear Martin is  domesticity. It's the greatest fear  that men have who belong to Western  Culture. It's centuries old. Like  King Phillip, in the 11th or 12th  century who decided one day that he  was so bored with his dreary life at  home with his wife he thought, "Well,  wouldn't it be great if we hit the  road and fought... oh... the  Saracens."  So he put the word out  and was amazed when a million men  signed up and all of them wanted to  go and fight in distant lands and do  terrible things to people rather  than stay at home with their families.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying that Ulysses-- everything he said to his queen when  he came back--everything was a lie?  He just wanted to fuck around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how have you been feeling about  your... work lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uneasy. Dispassionate. Bored. It's  just getting hard to go to work in a  good mood. I'm starting to think  I've been in the business too long.  Last week I did a guy younger than  me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: From the back of the darkened empty church, we see him mo the altar.  A priest in fact.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S HANDS
dialogues.text: open the gilded doors to reveal the chalice. He removes i squirts a clear liquid into the cup, and swishes it out. returns the chalice to the cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church seems to be purging itself  of it's pedophile.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sits in the back pew of the church, now crowded for Mann. watches the PRIEST lift the chalice into the air, murmur prayer, and drink from it. The Priest collapses behind th altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bull market.

dialogues.speaker: C.U. OF ALTAR CARPET
dialogues.text: The chalice bounces free from the Priest's hand as it hit the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, that never use to happen. I  was always the prodigy. Now I'm just  one of the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe some of the discomfort you're  feeling is... guilt. Remorse. Over  the innocent people you've killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I show up at your door, chances  are you did something to bring me  there. I don't care about that stuff,  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morality. Oatman's glad the session's just about over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to your reunion, Martin. See those  people and discover what they mean  to you. Try not to kill anybody for  a few days, see how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I get antsy I'll kill a few small  animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're making progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very dark. No pictures or plants. Almost no furniture, an what he does have is black. The only sign of life is a CA The cat watches on as Martin sorts through a cardboard bo finally coming to a photo album.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teen-aged Martin Blank: shy boy with a nervous smile. H poses with his mother, an older woman with a kind smile.. but her eyes are dark; aged by a life of work and worry. the opposing page is a gilt funeral announcement that rea

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: turns the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photograph of a tall, thin girl: a bright smile from wi a bulky winter coat. A girl he's always wondered about: D NEWBERRY. Handwritten on the photo in girlish loops: "Wou you rather...?!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin pulls himself away from the album and the cat foll him, moaning hungrily--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Food soon... Martin opens a restaurant-style refrigerator. It holds va bottles of vitamins, spirulina, wheatgrass, digestible  hydrogen peroxide, fluoride treatment, oxygenated mouth r and thirty cans of CATFOOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuna or liver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuna it is. He opens a can for the cat and a bottle for himself. Whil the cat eats, he returns to the cardboard box. Finds a  YEARBOOK. Flips it open....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A picture of a senior class "Blues Brothers" party: a gro of teens mug to the camera in Blues Brothers get-ups.  Sprinters race for a finish line, their chests stretching for the tape.

dialogues.speaker: DEBI NEWBERY'S SENIOR PICTURE
dialogues.text: A more mature version of the girl in the album. Her name  appears under his picture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Track light fills the gourmet-rustic kitchen. GROCER stan wearing a burgundy Fila sweat suit, pushing beets into a  vegetable juicer. Next to the juicer are piles of celery carrots, as well. A low-key BLIP is heard from another ro Grocer tops off the glass and takes it out of the kitchen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grocer enters the main room of the villa-style A-frame. H moves to an antique oak desk and sits in front of a COMPU

dialogues.speaker: ON-SCREEN GRAPHICS
dialogues.text: "Click OK for remote access caller"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK is clicked. "Availability for two days in Detroit area" "Terms"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "When" "Now" "OK/ FAX materials"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grocer leans back in his chair and sips the juice. After moment, the FAX machine on the desk rattles. The computer beeps. "confirmation number of wire transfer#: AJ6687-OI99471" Grocer hits the return button after taking in the number. graphic appears: "Connection is terminated/ Status idle" Grocer's FAX begins to moan and chatter. Grocer raises hi juice glass to the computer in a lazy toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin reclines in first class, soaring toward the Midwes on the red-eye. He has already scanned his magazines and  they are piled in the empty seat next to him. He sets asi a Powerbar. Martin reads Kill Without Joy. After a moment he sets the book down and takes up Iron John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the edge of the airport bar sits LARDNER and MCCULLERS two Government Spooks, agency unknown. They are both in  blazers, no ties, early thirties, and they watch the pass crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always say that. You always say  that. I'm telling you, you never met  the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen months ago I was posting a  walk in Lisbon, and he was there. He  never saw me. But I saw him, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisbon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Portugal, yes. In the background, Martin passes by them as he walks down the hall. Without directly regarding him, the two stand,  drop some cash on the bar, and begin to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the news: He hasn't been in  Portugal since '90. I know that from  the file. Why don't you read the  file, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, I think I talked with him,  in Bonn. Lardner can neither confirm nor deny this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always say that. You always have  to know everybody. Why don't I just  take the weekend off and let you  kill him. Since you two are so close. They exit.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE MARTIN'S CAR
dialogues.text: Martin, in a black Lincoln Town Car, veers off of the air artery and on to a turnpike. The radio broadcasts the new

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...with highs today in the upper  seventies. Related stocks on Wall  Street today as scandal continues to  rock the joint U.S.-Japanese Tech  Center...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S CAR
dialogues.text: blows past CAMERA and on down the road. After a beat, a m eighties Ford Country Squire station wagon follows, occup by two figures.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE COUNTRY SQUIRE
dialogues.text: are Lardner and McCullers. They listen to the same broadc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...An unknown "whistle-blower" has  leaked a number of critical flaws in  the safety designs of next year's  models to authorities that could  cost millions in recalls....

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: flips through the dial, pausing on Rush Limbaugh who waxe fascistically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mein hero. ...and then turns the dial again and cuts in on "Armagedd Time," slow reggae vibe by The Clash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin drives down the roadway... headlong into his past. Dig it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin turns up the volume as he reacts to a familiar  voice....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --this is WFRN, all vinyl, all the  time. Oldies from the eighties. It's  a cold summer day in Grosse Pointe--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lit only by dime slivers of sunlight, in front of a  microphone. Stray, gossamer strands of hair hanging in he face move in front of her mouth as she speaks....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and I'm ready for some good tunes  and angry talk. Or angry tunes and  good talk--

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: looking somewhere far away, beyond what is before him in windshield...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Or maybe we'll just play the Cocteau  Twins and get over the goo-angry- talking music. As you know--

dialogues.speaker: THE DEEJAY'S HANDS
dialogues.text: as they distractedly toy with the wire at the base of the mic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --for some moments in life there are  no words, and a little nonsense now  and then is relished by the wisest  man--

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: still rapt, makes a sharp turn into a shopping district.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --The Cocteau Twins, though also a  band of the nineties, will be aired  due to the fact that they created  their own language to sing by--

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: slows on a quaint street of cute shops. He creeps up to a storefront on hid right and stops, staring through the  passenger window....

dialogues.speaker: DEBI NEWBERRY
dialogues.text: the female deejay. She sits slumped in a well-worn execut chair, her back to the studio console and the picture win behind it that opens to the street....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Now that's freedom-- she swivels in the chair to face the street.... DEBI'S P.O.V. of Martin's Town Car outside, Martin silhouetted in shado

dialogues.speaker: DEBI
dialogues.text: Her brow furrowed as she peers at the car, something summ by the dark figure. Her words falter almost imperceptibly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --The best I can do is a rhyme: Where  are all the good men dead? In the  heart or in the head? Back later....

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Shaken from his trance by her stare, pulls back into the  street and disappears....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin drives, listening to the radio. He turns the corne with an expectant look on his face. Suddenly his face dro as he slows and pulls over....

dialogues.speaker: 7-11 STORE
dialogues.text: Martin looks left of the store, then right, behind him, t back at the store. Bewildered, he gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Martin as he walks with purpose. He halts in the middl of the lot. He puts his hands on his hips, stares, then m in... We stay wide as he enters the store and addresses t clerk inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? CARL, the store clerk tries to get a grip on this questio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A double shift. What's it look like? (softening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you with something? Martin's head pans the room, processing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin continues to gaze at the structure as if it's a lu landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Oatman. Dr. Oatman. Please pick  up if you're there... It's Martin  Blank. It's gone. My house. It's not  here. My house is gone and now there's  a 7-11 here... And that's  unfortunate... You can never go home  again, Dr. Oatman. Martin hangs up. He watches one-stop shoppers come and go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I guess you can shop there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of a NURSE leading him down a drab, antiseptic hallway. S banks into the sunlit room where a wispy woman in her lat fifties sits expectantly on the edge of the bed clutching her purse in one hand, a filterless Pall-Mall in the othe a light coat on. This is MARY BLANK. She suffers from  Alzheimer's or something just as debilitating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, your son's here. The nurse gently eases Mary up. Martin hugs Mary stiffly pats her shoulders. Mary takes hold of Martin's arm. They start out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk past a school-yard park fitted with a set of sw baseball diamonds, and a small grove of trees. She smokes and hacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought a new rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's wonderful, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a revival tent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a place where religious people--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlin Perkins and Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His assistant. He acted like Marlin's  son, only he wasn't. At least they  never said he was... I bet they were  lovers, faggots. Yes, gay lovers.  Wild Kingdom my ass! Mary coughs horribly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to see you. I'm sure you're  curious about what I've been doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke to your father the other  day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I imagine that'd be rather difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nature made him then broke the mold. Martin decides to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They told me you're taking lithium,  mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they give me headaches. I have  a headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a headache?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a headache. You have a  headache?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have a headache. I have a  headache. Mary leans in close, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a good laugh, didn't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess we did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they head toward Martin's car, Mary stops and points t it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you return this car and  borrow mine? Have Debi follow you to  the rent-a-car so you can get a ride  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll go see Debi today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't think of anything to say to  her that seems appropriate given I  left and never said goodbye to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of her. She's a keeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a leader. Didn't she meet Castro  on foreign exchange?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have always thought about her and  missed her. A nurse approaches with a wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Separate the wheat from the chaff  and you've got the candle cat. Together, Martin and the nurse help Mary into it. Mary ga at Martin, taking him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember no matter how impossible  your problems feel. I've known people  without a chance in the world. And  all of a sudden, they have lives.   Time allows miracles. Let yourself  breathe, son. Martin bends down and kisses her on the cheek. The nurse  spins the chair around and heads toward the building. He somewhat fatigued from the experience, but he tries once  more to connect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom... The nurse stops and turns Mary around to face him. Mary l up at Martin and brightens. She starts to sing out like E Merman, arms out Broadway style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What's up doc/ what's cookin'?/  What's up doc?/ Are ya lookin'?/  Hey! Look out!  You're gonna hurt  someone,/ with that old shotgun,/  Hey... what's... up... Doooooc...!/  We really mean it!" Mary stops short, and squints at Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you're a handsome devil. What's  your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stops the car and looks out the window at the sea headstones. He jerks his hand in a stiff wave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Pop... You got off easy. The  house is a 7-11. Mom's a psycho- pharmacological punching bag and I  murder for cash. If you were here I  think you'd be proud. He drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room features a big square bed, dresser and televisio Martin enters, kicks a leather bag under the bed, and gra the steel-sided briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pries out a wall vent, slides in the  case and replaces the vent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner and McCullers are staked out along the main strip town. Lardner snores, face pressed up against the passeng window. McCullers lays back in his seat, a to-go cup in h lap. He taps the cup with one finger as he absently sings his favorite Bob Seeger song to himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Against the wind... just a young  man running... Against the wind...  let the cowboy's ride!... Blame on  it the thuuunder! Night moves..." McCullers catches of Martin's Town Car coming down the st He nudges Lardner, and points. LARDNER AND MCCULLERS P.O.V. of Martin pulling into a space on the street outside the  radio station. He gets out, looking nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi flips on the "ON-AIR" switch and prepares to speak i the microphone. Martin walks in. Debi sees him. They star at each other. The song ends. Dead air. After a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on air, groping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WRFN playing all vinyl, all the time.  Oldies from the eighties. That was  ah... the Specials. Doing... one of  their songs... Debi turns to turntable B and finds it empty. She turns b to turntable A and lets the record roll on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and here's another. Debi swivels around to face Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oldies from the eighties?" After a long pause....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just play my own collection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to see you again. Debi says nothing, just stares at him, in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has it been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you stood me up on prom night  and vanished without saying a word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten years, I think. What I miss? Debi slowly grooves into irony, her best defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let me see... they tore down  the George Orwell monument and put  up a bust of George Michael. Main  Street's a four-laner, no left turns  four to seven. I was married and  divorced. And Grosse Pointe is now  officially the new sister city to  Lower Hutt, New Zealand. We have  fiber-optic town meetings every two  months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is now there. There is here. Their eyes lock on each other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are the headlines. The request line buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold that thought. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WRFN FM, Grosse Pointe. All vinyl,  all the... (pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Pearl Jam. Call back in ten years. Beat. Debi makes the move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in California most of the time.  Traveling a lot on business. That's  about it, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a professional killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professional killer. Do you get dental  with that? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm in town for a few days,  anyway. They run out of words, the moment too big for small talk. Martin gets the fear, breaks it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I gotta go. But I'll come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Martin leaves Debi sitting alone, in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin steps out of the storefront station along the  fashionable Grosse Pointe shopping district. He stops in middle of the street with a strained look on his face. INT. LARDNER & MCCULLERS' COUNTRY SQUIRE - SAME LARDNER & MCCULLERS' P.O.V. of Martin standing in the street.

dialogues.speaker: LARDNER AND MCCULLERS
dialogues.text: They frown, wondering at Martin's next move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi lost in thought, still. After a moment, she sits upr and flips the "ON-AIR" switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man comes to you. He is from the  past bringing you pain long since  put behind you. He says peculiar  things and leaves abruptly. It all  comes flooding back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stops in his tracks. His face softens, then become determined. He turns and walks back toward the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi broadcasting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It felt like an apparition, or some  cheap, gruesome Rod Serling time  warp I'd been thrust back into without  warning. There's a strangeness in  the air and I don't mind telling  you, I'm a little spooked. He was a  man from my past. A man I loved. A  man who disappeared. DEBI'S P.O.V. of Martin walking back into the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who's walking back into the  station. Martin comes into the booth. The temperature rises as the square off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, remember when Frysal's men  paid off the Deejay in Cairo to  announce a bogus press conference in  the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Nooo--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Yes. And the Munich Olympics in  '72. A local radio station started  broadcasting news of the massacre  two minutes before it happened. McCullers is not to be outdone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's strictly BГ ader-Meinhof stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the PLO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Debi locked in a passionate embrace. They brea away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit. Martin obeys. Debi clandestinely flips the "ON-AIR" switc as she drops into her chair. The "ON-AIR" light bar goes above and behind Martin. Unbeknownst to him their convers is put out over the airwaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right mystery man. I want some  answers. Let's recap. Spring of '84.  Two young lovers with frightening  natural chemistry. The girl sits in  a seven-hundred dollar prom dress at  her father's house waiting for the  most romantic night of her young  life. The boy never shows up, until  now. So, what's the question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have I been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More like what happened? What  happened, Mr. Blank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know exactly. I could venture  a guess but it would sound like a  rationalization... I thought you  know... maybe seeing you, some  friends, my house... of course now a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Torn down in the name of convenience--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and I guess, sure, seeing you would  be part of that whole equation... I  suppose the most important thing,  really. I don't know. Anyway, this  whole thing's my therapist's idea.  It's my shrink, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhh. You're in therapy too, Marty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no. So you're back now, a decade  later, and you want to sort things  out with me. The question now is, do  I allow you... access... to my being? Martin says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then. Would you like to  share any more deeply personal  thoughts with our listening audience  before we go to our phone poll and  see how the folks in radioland come  down on this one? A beat as Martin realizes he's been had. He seems about t bolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should a broken-hearted girl give a  guy a second chance at love.... Debi jabs a phone line on the console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (HARD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on the air. Martin deflates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this young man has avoided  the question completely. Has not  discussed "what happened" nor if  he's sorry for what he has done.  Therefore, I don't see any reason  why you should see him until he fully  discloses his intentions and feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you caller. Stabs another line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the guy. Martin looks up, humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... when you guys use to go out...  Did you guys ever... heh heh heh  heh... ever fuckin', ever totally  fuckin' heh heh heh-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next caller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Debi. Sounds like bad  gas to me. I would not allow him  access to your being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grosse Pointe Michigan, I hear you  loud and clear: "If you love something  set it free. If it comes back to you  it's, well... She turns to him and shrugs apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Broken...." Martin has his answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin leaves the station, alone and beaten down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit. Never trust my instincts. He scans the main strip. MARTIN'S P.O.V. A MAN walks down the street. He is FELIX, a bookish,  forgettable man in his forties, wearing Le Coq Sportif sw and shoes. He looks as if he has a dark cloud over his he Martin's seen him somewhere, and doesn't like what he  remembers. Martin's POV TRACKS him. FELIX'S P.O.V. As he walks down the street, he spots the Country Squire, and eyes Lardner and McCullers in the front seat. MARTIN'S P.O.V. follows Felix's eyes to Lardner and McCullers and catches their look. Their eyes lock, neither wanting to betray th they've made each other. They all do a pretty good job. H P.O.V. swings to a square-jawed, hale fellow wearing dark sunglasses who is approaching directly and only a few fee away. The man is going for something in his breast pocket Reaches into his own jacket, most likely for a gun....

dialogues.speaker: THE MAN
dialogues.text: pulls out a glasses case, and takes off his shades-- He i PAUL SWIDERSKI.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND PAUL
dialogues.text: Martin relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning ear-to-ear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I would've voted for you, but  there's all this apple sauce stuck  in my phone... I don't wanna talk  about it. How the hell are you?! (extends his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's five good ones! No trace of recognition on Martin's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty! It's me. Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're leaving me hanging here... They shake. Martin looks him up and down, astonished at t respectable veneer of his old burn-out friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Give me a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Paul rive through Grosse Pointe, Michigan: Wid streets lined with huge, shady oaks. Castle-like homes on golf-course green lawns. A comfortable, Midwestern Beverl Hills. They are cruising their old haunts, Paul smoking a joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This won't take but a minute. I just  gotta hold their hands for a final  walk-through. I'll take them in, get  'em out, then you and I can grab a  little quality time. Martin looks out the window, breathing in the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn, It's good to see you. I was  afraid you joined a cult or something.  I half-expected you to come back to  town in a fennel wreath and paper  pants. Paul offers Martin the joint. He declines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no money in it. Martin regards Paul archly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same thing that happened to you-- I  stopped poutin' there on the  sidelines. Got in. Got on the team.   I joined the working week, you slick  fucking asshole, so why don't you  valet park your high horse and take  it easy on your old buddy, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God it's great to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of a lovely YOUNG COUPLE on the front porch of a mid-size Wright home... Perhaps that could be him if things were  different, but for now it feels like along shot. Paul is  hawking the house to them out of earshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we do what we have to do if we  find you on the property. But we  don't really enforce the law, we  execute company policy for homeowners.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND THE GUARD
dialogues.text: standing in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when are you authorized to use  deadly force?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, a 'course, taxes provide your  basic service-- police and whatnot.  But our customers need a little more  than just that, you understand? This  badge doesn't mean that I am a peace  officer. The woman turns at Martin and smiles. Martin smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's not a meaningful symbol, or  anything. That badge is just the  badge of your company. If I look  suspicious on your customers' property-- well, under those heightened  circumstances you have the authority  to, ah... To shoot me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To shoot you. Correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get this job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they were hiring, and it was  only a two week course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Paul walks the happy couple down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to couple)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What more can I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (much hand gesturing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be raising your new family in  a work of art. A work of art in a  work of art. Paul looks at Martin and the Guard, inviting them into th sell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you'll be very happy. All look to Martin....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartfelt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When my time comes, if it ever does,  I want a beautiful, normal place  like this... and a wife like you... All are confused. Martin thumbs to the guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and you'll be safe here... Paul looks at his shoes and rolls his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner and McCullers sit in the wagon, watching the hous in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Paul cut through a particularly charming  neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. I don't make a habit of pimping  my friends, but there is one prime  little piece of land that you must  see... MARTIN'S P.O.V. A sprawling gingerbread mansion rises into view. A long a winding driveway cuts through thickly wooded property to house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of crept up on you, didn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You drove us here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it's still kind of eerie,  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Martin's not listening. His eyes track the house out the  window. MARTIN'S P.O.V. of the mansion. They roll slowly by Debi's house. They drive in silence for a beat. Paul suddenly swerves t the shoulder, jams the brake, and turns on Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten years. What happened!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I freaked out, joined the Army, worked  for the government, and went into  business for myself... I'm a  professional killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Paul, satisfied, gets back on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professional killer, huh? Does that  come with a good HMO?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul makes a turn. They approach a large car dealership. sign above it says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking ahead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sells BMW's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sold me this bad boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you put your hard-earned  dollars into the hands of the class  bully?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave me a great deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mein Dealer. Paul slows outside the lot. BOB DESTEPHANO-- a big, angry looking man in an expensive suit-- stands in the lot, puf up amidst his stable of expensive cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Bob! The car's running great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to hear it. Bob turns his back on them and begins to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me. Martin Blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really...? So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin climbs out of Paul's car and begins to walk toward his own. Paul calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you at the left-a-boy-came-back- a-man-made-good party. Martin nods him off. Paul pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: stands across the street from the radio station, looking Debi in the window... Martin draws a thin rifle scope fro his back pocket, and lifts it to his eye...

dialogues.speaker: SCOPE
dialogues.text: of Debi, in the crosshairs, bored, tapping a pencil to th beat of an unheard song.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: dejected. He puts the scope away and gets in his car.

dialogues.speaker: INT. 7-11
dialogues.text: Martin walks into the store, looking around once again at his old home. To the left of the door, a typical suburban teenage SKATEBOARDER is lost in the "Mortal Combat" video game and something too loud from his walkman. Carl, still working the double, nods to Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's done is done. Martin moves up one aisle to the gum rack. He picks out a pack of Beaman's and unwraps a stick as he heads to the  counter. On the way, he makes a black Town Car pulling in a spot next to his own. He immediately changes course, an bee-lines for a rear aisle where he ducks down...

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Comes through the door, drawing a Mac-10 for each hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: grabs the gum out of his mouth and sticks it onto the bot of the Glock .9mm he has produced from somewhere in his s

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: grabs the cash drawer, sets it on the counter, and puts h hands up.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKATEBOARDER
dialogues.text: Plays on.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX AND CARL
dialogues.text: Felix shoots CARL DEAD on his way toward

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Bolts up the cooler aisle. Bursts of FIRE follow him, tak out each freezer door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND FELIX
dialogues.text: EXCHANGE FIRE John Woo-style between the aisles of the cr store. Felix delivers a close-to-home burst as he jumps t counter, sending Martin diving out of view.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: pinned behind the Slurpee machine, pauses to reload his n two Glock nines. Martin steals a glance to get a bead on  Felix and is met with a salvo that rocks the Slurpee mach spattering him with several flavors... and that's all he take. Martin comes up BLASTING with both guns, but all th left of Felix is swinging doors and squealing tires. Martin moves to the cashier island, low to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKATEBOARDER
dialogues.text: Twitches and jerks, still absorbed in his game and oblivi to the surrounding carnage.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER ISLAND
dialogues.text: Martin crawls through the waist-level swinging door and m to Carl.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: is really dead. Martin rolls him over to check it out and finds

dialogues.speaker: A BOMB
dialogues.text: under the corpse.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Flips the corpse back on top of the device and leaps the  counter toward the doors. He grabs the shoulder or the  Skateboarder, who shrugs him off, annoyed--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck, man?! The video game screen explodes. Shot full of Martin's bul The Skateboarder reacts backward and Martin jerks him out the double doors.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 7-11
dialogues.text: The Skateboarder is running like crazy, and Martin's car peeling out in reverse as the 7-11 is blown to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin's hair is matted with Slurpee as he tries to drive and cool out. He sees his do in the mirror, pulls out a c and starts to comb it back into a slick Pat Riley style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin walks in, not looking half bad, considering. Debi  looks up from some reading. "NaГЇve Melody" by the Talkin Heads plays in the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to the reunion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not going. Is that why you're  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'll have a ball. You seem  to have everything everybody wants  when they go back. The car, the suit,  the watch. The look. That just leaves  the little things, like happiness,  character, point of view...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always the little things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wondering how you've been. How  you are. I'd like to catch up with  you. If it's possible. Beat as Debi considers. She spins her seat to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's catch up. You go first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's not much to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you've done worthwhile things  in the last ten years. You've had  experiences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad experiences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You met people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watched television?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Marty. You're pathetic. It  sounds like you need a Shockabuku.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a swift spiritual kick to the  head that alters your reality forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd be good. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want? The question is open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured I could pick you up tomorrow  around seven o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight, are you  asking me out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a crisp and starry night, a man and a woman sit aro a campfire. As we MOVE CLOSER we see that the woman is  Marcella reading, "Women Who Run With Wolves."  She tends s'mores on the campfire, assembles one, and hands it to M her young outdoorsman boyfriend. Monty is perched on a sm boulder, engaged in a Tai-Chi-like ritual, wearing Patago finest. There is a path of crystals leading from the fire the boulder. In the background is a tent and a Nissan  Pathfinder. Monty's watch goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, it's eight o'clock. Marcella gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Monty. She tousles Monty's hair on the way to the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcella gets in. She shuts the door and dials the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there, how'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin sits on the edge of the bed in a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't done. Marcella pauses, taking this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it tomorrow. Marcella considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't looked at the dossier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've looked at it. Martin eyes the vent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's the same as usual. Nothing  remarkable about it at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to call the client and give  them a reason why you're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them my house exploded. Beat. Marcella doesn't know what to make of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call them and tell them you're  taking your time. Being a  professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, call them. Fine. Oh-- And if  you could find out why they double- booked the job, and who is trying to  kill me, and call me back-- that's  be great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will do. Martin hangs up. He moves up to the air vent, deciding to get down to business. He pries it open, and withdraws his briefcase, putting it down on the bed and propping it ope He looks at the unopened dossier for a moment, flips it o in his hands, and tosses it on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: BRIEFCASE
dialogues.text: We catch a glimpse of Martin's weapons. Martin picks up t envelope and is about to tear the seal when

dialogues.speaker: THE PHONE RINGS
dialogues.text: Martin drops the envelope and lifts the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick me up at my father's house at  around seven. And don't be late this  time. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This night, this reunion will be an  important step in our relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fucking psycho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't rush to judgement until all  the facts are in. She hangs up. Martin smiles and replaces the receiver. He turns to the apparatus laid out on the bed. GUNS, BULLETS, ETC. What has been his life is beginning to look more like dea to him. He places the envelope in the case, then returns case to its hiding place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner and McCullers stake out Martin from the Country S across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish he'd do his job already so we  could do our job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't do our job unless he does  his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we just do his job then,  so we can do our job, and get the  fuck out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do his job? I'm not a cold-blooded  killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -Look. You want to kill a Good Guy,  but not be a Bad Guy, you wait until  a Bad Guy kills the Good Guy, and  then you come in and kill the Bad  Guy, and then you're the Good Guy.
