dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if we do his job, we're the bad  guys. If we do our job, we're the  good guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. They both laugh, as if at some great joke. Their laughter caught short by the sight of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moving into the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin sits in a window booth splitting nutrient caplets  into an apple juice and looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: GROCER
dialogues.text: slides into the booth, across from Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND GROCER
dialogues.text: Martin draws a nasty little PPK pistol from his waist, an levels it at Grocer under the table-- but Grocer is alrea drawing his pistol down there, and there is an instant Me breakfast stand-off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, tiger. A waitress approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Welcome to B.I. McCafferty's. My  name is Melanie and I'll be your  server this morning. Let me tell you  about some of our specials. Today we  have the "Alfalfa on My Mind," our  feature omelette. And there's our  "Gatsby's West Egg Omelette." And if  you're in the mood for something  different there's the "I left my  heart in San Franchezie." Martin and Grocer's eyes remain locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want two eggs poached, hash brown  well-done. English muffin for the  bread. And a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whole-grain pancakes. And an egg- white omelette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like in the omelette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing in the omelette. Nothing at  all. The waitress nods pertly and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the omelette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, live a little. I'm sorry  about the incident yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No harm no foul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little misunderstanding among my  associates. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told them to kill you and they  didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to get good help these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But since we're both here, I think  it's time to take a fresh look at  our relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get into this business to  have "associates." And I don't want  to join your Goddamned union. "Loner-- " "Loner gunman." Get it? "On my  own." That's the whole point. Why  don't you become a cop, or something.  You can drink coffee in the morning...  with friends! Grocer looks a little hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easing up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is a one-on-one business...  Every time you get to know people,  bad things happen. If it'll make you  feel any better, this is my last  job. So what do you say we put our  guns away and forget the whole damn  thing. Grocer loses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you! No scabs! From now on,  everything's regulated! Long beat as Grocer gets a hold of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. But we're not going to let you  do your job. Because we're gonna do  it. And then, after we do your job,  we're gonna do another little job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Wry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah-- after I shoot you through the  fucking forehead I'm gonna fuck you  in the bullethole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice talk, Sugarmouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin sits at a desk, staring at the reunion card. He to it aside, gets up, and moves in front of a mirror. He wea a crisp black suit and practices his greeting smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying on smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm a pet psychiatrist. I sell  couch insurance. I test-market  positive thinking. I lead a weekend  men's group, actually. We specialize  in ritual killings. I'm hungry, are  you hungry, I'm hungry, oooh, ooh. (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Martin Blank, remember me?   I'm not married, I have no kids and  I'd blow your brains out if someone  paid me enough... So how've you been?  Where do you stand on The Issues?  Are you Left? Right? Up, down, proud,  shamed, blahblahblahblah--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin makes his way up the walk leading to the front doo holding a simple bouquet of flowers. He skips up the fron steps and finds the doorbell. After a moment, Debi answer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flowers. That's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as I get the laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Let me put these in some rubbing  alcohol. She backs into the house, and he follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin follows Debi into the hall. Both are enjoying this atavistic ritual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Hold on... MARTIN'S P.O.V. through a doorway leading into a den. All that's visible MR. NEWBERRY, Debi's father, is a pair of legs resting in Barcolounger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Let me get my coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just help myself to a cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: DEBI
dialogues.text: moves up the stairs and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: looks at the legs, rolls his shoulders, and heads into th den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Newberry sits in the recliner reading a Tom Clancy no He is a corporate Aspen-dude-ranch sort with a good head hair. He sighs, closes the book on his knee and looks up Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Newberry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you? How's business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin, I don't know where you've  been since you abandoned my daughter  ten years ago, and I don't care. It  was good that you left, and I'm glad  you did. So what do you want to talk  about? You've grown up a bit. Maybe  I had you figured wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I visualized you, in a haze, as one  of the slackster, flannel-wearing,  coffeehouse-misanthropes I've been  seeing in Newsweek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took the other road. I'm more of a  self-reflective young lion who does  business with lead-pipe cruelty and  goes home to drink light beer in  milky-eyes isolation. I love sports  and sex and have no real relationships  with anyone. And you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know me, Martin. I'm the  same old sell-out baby-boomer,  exploiting the oppressed I got shot  for at Kent State. But why don't we  have a drink and forget the whole  thing? Newberry lays down his book, and moves behind the wet bar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you doing with your life  now, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a professional killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. Debi's footsteps are heard coming down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay Mr. Newberry watches Martin turn and walk out of the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Debi pull away from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Debi drive through that to Debi is town, and t Martin is a widening pool of quicksand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to get a drink first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they'll probably have booze  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Martin's right hand shakes off of the wheel a bit. He gri it tighter. Suddenly, Martin turns the wheel and pulls in a gas station parking lot, halting next to a pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just be a second. Debi nods, a little confused but going with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stands at the kiosk next to the Town Car, mid- conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, I didn't kill anyone, but  someone tried to kill me and the guy  in the middle got killed. So if I  see that guy again I'm definitely  going to kill him, but I won't kill  anyone else. Oh, except for the guy  I was sent here to kill. I don't  know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oatman treats his patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else? Say more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw my mom... I'm with Debi, and I'm  on my way to the reunion. In the background, Lardner and McCullers drive past the  station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Repeat this after me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out Loud? Martin looks to Debi. She looks up and smiles. We hear Dr Oatman's command, Martin mumbles them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I am at home with the me. I am  rooted in me, who is on this  adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a deep breath and realize, that  this is me breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is me breating. Martin takes in a few breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, look. I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't kill anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Don't kill anyone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felix rummages delicately around the room. He goes to the

dialogues.speaker: NIGHTSTAND
dialogues.text: The reunion invite.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: picks it up and scans it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner and McCullers sit it the parking lot. They watch  Martin and Debi pull into a space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's falling for her. Look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He using her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wrong. Look at his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One cannot love and kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love. I kill.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND DEBI
dialogues.text: climb out of the car. Martin, breathing deeply and wiping his sweaty palms, leans against the car and tries to calm himself. Eighties music echoes from the gym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoulda brought my gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? He pulls himself off the car and heads toward

dialogues.speaker: GROSSE POINTE HIGH SCHOOL
dialogues.text: A sprawling red-brick Gothic structure with many wings. I is topped by church-like towers. It's scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Debi enter and pause to take in the entire sce A benevolent Ronald Reagan hangs crookedly above. Basketb nets are swung back, draped with crepe. Lights are half-l and the music is loud. Alumni are dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back! I'm Arlene Oslott- Joseph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Martin Blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi Newberry. Debi heads off into the gym, smiling back as she strands  Martin. Arlene rises from a card table. They have little say. Martin wasn't part of her crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty, you haven't changed a bit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that. Arlene gives him a NAMETAG. As a special torture, the tag have YEARBOOK PHOTOS. Martin looks at the name tag  uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had pictures put on, that way  everybody knows who everybody was!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what are you doing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever I can get away with. She smiles at his joke and is immediately distracted by t next arrival. Martin moves off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the next person)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it cute. It's so everybody  knows who everybody was! He circles the crowded gym. Looking for familiar faces. H stops at the open bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I make you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beer. The bartender gets him a beer. Martin recognizes a guy at the bar. He is well-appointed and shiny. He is KEN ALDRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ken. How have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at Martin's  name tag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Martin. How have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad. You? Bob Destephano arrives next to them and orders a drink. E contact is made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bob. Bob turns slightly toward them. They continue in their  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an attorney. I'm with Moss, Brice  & Fromeyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds pretty interesting... Bob wants to join the conversation but doesn't know how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes. I'm in divorce, mainly.  Some property. Some personal injury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those all seem kind of related... Bob takes another drink and mopes off, Martin watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tragedy makes you thirsty. Ken chuckles. The bartender arrives with the bottle. Mart grabs it and begins to move off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I have to take this over to  Debi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Take my card. Wait a minute...  here's a special one. For top-shelf  clients. Ken hands Martin a Monte Blanc pen with Ken's title and  business address printed on the shaft. Martin reads it an puts it in his kerchief pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Ken goes back to listening to the Guys at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: makes his way through the upbeat crowd of well-wishers. T emerges like an inkspot on a clean white whirt, and inter Martin. His angst is barely under control as he sidles up Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Blank, all these fucking  people, driving me crazy. Look at  them over there, memorializing old  times, acting all like it was  something "life-changing." And the  people in the National Honor Society?  The name tags? Martin shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have special blue starts on  them like it fucking matters now  that they were in the honor club ten  years ago. I'm getting fucking  nauseous from all this sentimental  bullshit. It's making me sick. Terry stops suddenly as if he's finished. Martin reads th man's nametag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here... Terry? Terry turns on a dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to see a couple people. But  I don't want to talk about the old  days... What did we have together,  Martin? Typing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drafting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I couldn't stand that fucking  class. But I appreciate you helping  me out, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks. Well I'm going to try  and get out of here, man. I'll see  you later. Terry slinks off.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Bob Destephano grabs two more scotches off the bar and tu to leave, thoroughly morose. In his path, he finds DAN  KORETZKY, the good-looking side of brainy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob. Bob Destephano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Dan. Dan Koretzky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Computer guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... Hey, I saw you at your dad's  dealership the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sell BMW's. What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much, actually. My software  company just went public so I'm  just... hanging out, really. There's a sudden lull in the conversation. Bob tries his  drunken hand at relating...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember high school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Listen. Why don't you join us  up in the grandstands? Dan points up to a group of happy, laughing people. Bob w off shaking his head and smiling bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi and Martin are seated at a round table with six othe in an area blocked off for dinner. Plates of gumbo are  arriving and the wine is poured. DARIUS, an African-Ameri is in mid-conversation with AMY, who looks like she walke out of a Laura Ashley catalog and sits on the other side Martin. DENNIS and MIKE are two suits in the midst of a n stop sports conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You gotta hold the fans  responsible, though, Dennis, because  they're the ones putting up with the  mediocre product.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess, though, you know, if you  look at it Mike, that park is a  beautiful park, I've gone to that  park many times - I've had the  greatest time of my life at that  ballpark and let's face it, I tell  you this, Mike, by the sixth inning,  if you're having the fun you should  be having at Tigers Stadium, you  don't even know what the hell's going  on anyway... They both crack up at this. ANGLE ON DARIUS, MARTIN, & DEBI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you two been together since  high school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Yes. Actually we just bought that  little Frank Lloyd Wright on Pine  Avenue... Debi's a social worker and  I mow down insurance claims at Aetna--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't seen each other since  high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured. You two look too happy  together. I shouldn't say that though,  I'm married... So, Martin-- what are  you up to these days? What do you do  for a living? Debi perks up; this should be interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in pro-active international  relations. It's a very specialized  company. We execute economic  investment opportunities. Sort of  economic clean-up... with an emphasis  on personnel. It's boring, you know,  it's boring. I don't like to talk  about it because I don't think what  a man does necessarily reflects who  he is... Martin begins to draw strange looks from all over the tab Martin may be in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I've always tried to refrain from  a black-and-white moral lexicon--you  know, good, bad, right, wrong--I've  been more interested in the gray  areas. Silence. Martin pushes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's no way to live. I guess  you've got to just take the leap of  faith. Believe in something. Fuck  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds complicated, Martin. Are you  happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have to close this one last  account. I'd like to just stop now,  today, but I can't... It's a step in  the right direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Martin. It sounds like  you're feeling compromised. Live the  way you want. The only thing that's  inexcusable, to me, is cynicism.  That's the biggest cop-out there is. Nods of assent come from around the table. A brief silenc and then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But wait. I still don't understand  what you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work at Kentucky Fried Chicken. Debi suppresses a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the corporate offices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sell biscuits to the Southland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so funny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sell biscuits and gravy all over  the Southland--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Stop it--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know those horsey biscuit gravy  packets? I move all of those--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes we sell them to McDonald's  and just change them to special  barbecue sauce. Across the table from Martin and Debi, Dennis turns to Da

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think about black coaching  in the NFL, Darius? Because I think  it's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't pay much attention to  football.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to agree with you Dennis.  It's good to see that the owners are  willing to put the franchise behind  a black head coach or QB when for  years in the league they've been  kept out of the thinking positions  and relegated mainly to the physical  game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now, you see, you have Warren  Moon at the helm, Cunningham, Art  Shell, and the coach up at  Minnesota...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis Green. And if you remember,  Doug Williams was the first black  man to prove that on a Superbowl  Sunday. Amy leans in to Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Martin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm teaching art at Cedar Junior  High School.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, listen. Where do you stand  on this whole Louis Farrakhan  issue...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (facetious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a De Klerk man myself. Debi nods, indicating to the deejay stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going over to play some tunes. Martin watches her walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan Koretzky sits with two other FORMER-SQUARES-turned- handsome-fellas who now enjoy a confidence that comes wit early investment in Microsoft. Martin looks out over the milieu below, enjoying the seen He eavesdrops on a group of men from a few rows back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at her. There it is. Jenny  Slater. The finest thing that ever  walked these halls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe she married the state of  Maine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's around here somewhere.  What a shame. She would have looked  great in my fucking Bentley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my friends, Jenny Beam. Not only  was she as fine, if not finer, than  Slater, but she had the "bad girl"  thing going for her. And the red  hair. C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a paramedic in Skokie, Illinois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You both are mistaken. Jenny Maretti  was the finest. No question about  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three Jenny's. Three Jenny's.  All named Jenny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm really hoping?  That Jenny Slater gets divorced. And  she's twenty-eight--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --she's got half the state of Maine--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's twenty-eight years old, with  two kids, she's still really really  fine, and I see her at a bookstore  or something, and she sees me for  what I was then, and what I am now:  the redemption for all her failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the redemption for all your  failure. They ponder this. Martin looks down on the gym, concentra on Debi.

dialogues.speaker: BOB DESTEPHANO
dialogues.text: Dancing drunkenly, miserable, like an unbalanced oranguta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin stands by Debi as she sits in for a set in the dee booth, on a raised stage. They are playing an old sophomo game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which would you rather...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Would you rather... commit  yourself sexually to a four-by-nine  cell with former President George  Herbert Walker Bush dressed as a  super-model for a month, or make  love to a otter on crank for a week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft. I'll take the junkie otter,  clearly! I'd let the little beast  scratch and claw all he wants...  Okay. Would you rather make love to  the candied corpse of Phyllis Diller--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --She's not dead---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a game...! Alright. Candied  Diller, or... wear a hot pork vest  across the desert with a fully  digested crab apple in your mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. I have to give this some thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, then. Clearly candied Diller. STACEY breaks the moment, looking up at the two, horrifie and unsure at what she's heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty! Debi! How are you! So many  people came, but I never expected to  see you Marty. Or you Debi... I  mean... because of what your  divorce... I didn't mean to say that.  I just meant you look so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you could play "Too  Shy'" by Kaja Goo Goo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacey, why don't you come up here  and take over for a little while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to. Stacey nods thanks and makes her way up into the booth as Martin and Debi make their way down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Martin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody thinks they know me now  that I'm divorced. She leads Martin toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to see you in private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Debi walk down the hallway, alone together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though I left, you never left  me. Not just memory but a substance  in my blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like heroin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too junky-kitschy. Deeper, deeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enjoying this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be. The physical substance of  love. Debi stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll accept that. Follow me. Together they move into what appears to be the Nurse's Of and close the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Debi make wild banshee love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner and McCullers watch Felix into the gym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like someone keeps trying to  do our job for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he does our job, he's our job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get it.

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: steps through the doorway he's standing in and strolls in the crowded gym. He wears the standard khaki-pants-blue-b combo, with no nametag. He's clearly too old for the clas of 1984.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Debi come out of the Nurse's Office. The post- coital mood is broken as they hear The Human League's "Do You Want Me, Baby?"  blasting from the gym. Martin and De tune in on the song for a moment, unhappy at remembering  that particular moment in pop music history. Debi looks t Martin, something must be done about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back.... Debi kisses him. They split up. Martin walks off, the hap we've seen him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and several others from the muscle-to-fat crew play a drunken scrimmage with a papier-mache table ornament foot that is coming unwound. Bob quarterbacks and begins to re a long, complicated, and forgotten play. Martin approache from behind Bob and glides through the ad-hoc line-up,  continuing down the hall. Bob yells "hike" as he stares a Martin, distracted. Bob's rushed upon and sacked. He lets the papier-mache ball drop and crack on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin walks down a silent, deserted hall of lockers and  classroom doors. The only sounds are his footsteps and th echoed strains of Iggy Pop's "Wild Child" from the distan gym. He stops at locker number 1963 and flips the dial: R back left-right again. It opens. He pops up the steel fal ceiling in the empty locker, fishes his hand in the openi and withdraws what he is looking for: an ancient joint. H holds it up and examines the now brown and dried reefer. grinds it into dust in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi comes out of the gym and starts down the hall, the m changed for the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin senses he is not alone. He turns to find Bob  Destephano. The big man holds a glass unsteadily and slur slightly when he speaks. Bob is looking sad and scary. He leans into Martin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. You and Debi. Gonna hit that  shit again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Bob. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Bob crumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh... it's all fucked up. Nothing  adds up to nothing... you work your  whole life, day in and day out-- try  to make sense of it all. One day  you're twenty-seven and what do you  get to show for it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could've been a contender, huh? Bob realizes he can't even express his own tragedy withou the use of cliches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart boy. Real smart. Let's see how  smart you are with my foot up your  ass! I'm gonna kick your ass! Martin steps to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you want to hit me, Bob?  Do you really believe that there's  some stored up conflict that needs  resolution between us? We don't exist.  There's nothing between us. So who  do you want to hit, Bob? It's not  me. Bob slumps against the lockers, deflated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be an actor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then express yourself, Bob. Bob frowns, trying to think of a way to express himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be honest... Bob backs up and lets out a huge, drunken caveman scream, then stops abruptly, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Martin. Bob backpedals down the hallway and out of sight. Martin  watches him stumble out of the hallway and bang through t doors of a stairwell, disappearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob slams through the doors and begins to stumble down th stairs. He encounters Debi, on her way up. He glances at but does not break stride. Debi gives him wide berth, and quickens her pace up the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin watches the doors swing to a stop. He exhales and  relaxes... AND THEN Spin-pivots on his right heel, as a B from a silenced pistol pierces the space where his head w a split-second before/ As he spins around, his right hand withdraws Ken's give-away pen from his kerchief pocket, p the cap off, and drive the pen up and through the throat his attacker--

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: impaled through the throat on the pen, his head snapped b

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND FELIX
dialogues.text: are frozen for a moment. Blood runs quickly down the fron of Felix's body, off of his shoes, and on to the floor. T stairwell doors band open. Martin's head turns toward the sound. His eyes lock onto

dialogues.speaker: DEBI
dialogues.text: who is frozen, horrified for a moment. She flees.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: looks back at

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: Dead.

dialogues.speaker: THE FLOOR
dialogues.text: A growing pool of blood.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Looks around wildly, holding Felix up against the lockers Above the lockers is a plastic banner proclaiming

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: rips it down from the wall with his free hand, wraps it a Felix, stuffs the body into his open locker, and slams it shut. He pulls off his shoes and socks, puts a sock over  each hand like mittens, and wipes up the small pool of bl He stuffs the socks into his pockets, takes off down the  hall, and bangs through the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin blasts through the upstairs doors to the grandstan looking for Debi below. She is nowhere to be found. He sc the party in progress-- It is the same frame of image as one in Oatman's office. In the middle of the floor, Terry slowly turns up to meet Martin's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: pulls the doors shut, and takes off down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin opens his locker, withdraws the corpse, and hefts over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brick-walled, darkly lit, and narrow. Martin bounds down steep steps with his load.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin hustles toward a cage door in front of him. He kic through it and dumps Felix into a canvas laundry cart on  casters and begins rolling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bangs open and light pours into the room from be Martin. He negotiates the cart over the dirt floor and st next to the furnace that heats the swimming pool. He paus and looks to the ceiling: the music from the reunion puls into the floor above him. Martin picks up a large metal b and works open the door on the hulking cast-iron furnace. white-hot blaze roars within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is winding down. A harried-looking Martin walks and looks around once more for Debi-- nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the Deejay booth. It is empty. He moves over to the bar and joins Ken Aldridge. He motio to the bartender who opens a beer for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen Debi Newberry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. They both look around at the last of the reunion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more things change, the more  they Goddamned well stay the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess. Before Ken can get started again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself, Ken. Thanks  for the pen. Martin walks out of the gym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is leaning against his Beemer, having a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was catching up with Bob Destephano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as you had a good time. Beat. Martin scans the lot for sign of Debi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now? Chase the girl? There is a beat of silence. Nothing seems worth saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't work out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get my head back into my  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work's good for the soul. Martin gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you see Debi, tell her I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you in ten years. Paul watches him leave. He almost stops him, but thinks b of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin hunches over his briefcase that lays open on the b

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN PULLS
dialogues.text: THE DOSSIER from the briefcase. It's seal is broken, but contents remain enclosed... He withdraws the package and  dumps the contents on the bed. His face registers muted s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dumb fucking luck...

dialogues.speaker: THE CONTENTS
dialogues.text: include various photos of MR. NEWBERRY, Mr. Newberry with Debi, and the house. The photos are mingled with official looking papers including credit reports, medical records, etc... Newberry's life. He cocks his head toward the door anticipating a... KNOCK He freezes, then plucks a gun tapped under a desk, and mo toward the door, pointing. Halfway to the door, his face body slacken. He lobs the gun onto the bed. With everythi gone wrong, there is nothing left to defend. He goes to t door and opens it, body relaxed, expecting a bullet... Debi moves past him into the room. She is completely calm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was trying to kill you, right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the other way around...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it something you've done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's something I do... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Professionally... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...About five years now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, when I left, I joined the  Army and took the service exam. They  found my psych results fit a certain  profile. A certain "Moral flexibility"  would be the best way to describe  it... I was loaned out to a CIA- sponsored program. It's called  "mechanical operations." We sort of  found each other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a government spook? Martin says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was, but no... yes... I was before,  but now I'm not. It's irrelevant,  really. The idea of governments,  nations, it's mostly a public  relations theory at this point,  anyway. But I'll tell you something,  until about five months ago, I really  enjoyed my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I started losing my taste for  it. Which usually means your time is  up. But then I realized it was  something entirely different... I  started getting the sneaking, dark  suspicion that maybe there was...  meaning to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Great, Martin, that's just  great. Meaning to life... Mmm....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like, that there's a point? An organic  connection between all living things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you along, Martin. You're  a sociopath!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sociopath kills for no reason. I  kill for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never could have kept this from  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's probably a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you come with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm staying here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll hide. She goes for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go. She stops at the door. Slowly, she turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't get to have me. You are a  monster, I'm a human being. We're  not going to mate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because I speak human, and  you speak monster. Debi bolts out of the room. Martin is left alone. Martin looks over at his gear on the bed. After a beat, h walks slowly over and surveys his tools. He picks up a  cleaning rag and begins to go over the weapons, absently  singing to himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What's up Doc? What's cookin'? What's  up Doc, are you lookin'...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning light comes through the slit in the curtains, pic up four or five exquisitely clean guns are laid out on th bed, almost geometrically spaced. Martin lifts one at a t checking their bores and actions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner and McCullers gear up. They each finish loading t last of many clips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grocer and Company, not in a Ford Passenger Van, veer off onto an exit ramp. Grocer has assembled a team of about n They draw different guns from their kit bags and begin  loading...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner and McCullers jam clips into their service autos knock the slides...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin finished loading his guns, and puts them in his ca He shuts it and moves for the door. On the way out he sto and looks himself in the mirror before exiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each car whooshes by camera, on its way to the inevitable

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcella has a cordless tucked between her shoulder and e and holds a two-gallon gas can. She moves from room to ro pouring gasoline onto the computers, desks, and piles of  paper stacked on the floor. She adds a splash to her copy "Women Who Run With the Wolves."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm bringing down the office now. She picks up her hard drive and smashes it on the floor.  It's cathartic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll put things right. Then I'll  find you. Silence on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apprehensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... why? Martin finishes his weapons check, and pulls out the doss

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I left you a little  something under your desk. Martin hangs up. Marcella goes to it and pulls loose from underneath a shr wrapped brick of $100 bills, probably a $100,000 or so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin makes his way down the road to the Newberry's. In distance, he sees a lone figure jogging on the shoulder,  away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grocer and Company are parked off to the side, watching  Newberry, in the distance, jog toward them. A SNIPER prep to blow Newberry's head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he approaches the figure, he recognizes it as Newberry he accelerates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grocer spots Martin's car speeding at Newberry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newberry stops jogging and turns to face the Town Car bea down on him. His face goes slack, expecting to be creamed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin roars straight at Newberry, his engine shrieking. the distance between them turns from yards to feet... Mar swerves hard, just missing Newberry and comes to a halt n to him, blocking the Sniper's line of fire. After a momen Newberry opens the passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is the matter with  you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was hired to kill you. It's  what I do, and come to think of it,  I told you that, but... Okay. I'm  not going to do it. Get in the car. He does. They drive on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's either because I'm in love with  your daughter, or because I have a  new-found respect for life. Or both.  But I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grocer and company watch in amazement. GROCER'S P.O.V. of Martin's car disappearing into Newberry's long and woo driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That punk is either in love with  that guy's daughter or he has new  found respect for life... Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin pulls up in front and stops. Both men scramble out and head toward the front door at a quick clip. Newberry shaken; Martin seems at ease, at home in his element.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? I build cars! They're paying  you to kill me? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a cost-cutting effort. They  can't afford a recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a leaky sunroof! A design  flaw! I reported a leaky sunroof!  You want to kill me because of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not me! Why does everybody think  it's personal?! They go through the front door and shut it behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grocer drops the van into gear and heads toward the drive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner and McCullers approach the scene. They get within viewing distance in time to see Grocer's Town Car turn in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go in through the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin's briefcase is open on the large oak table. The  contents of the dossier are spilled out onto the table.  Newberry and Debi watch him, dumbstruck, as he draws a hu Desert Eagle automatic and jerks back the slide. He turns Debi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sitting in my house on prom  night wearing that Goddamned rented  tuxedo, a corsage in one hand, a  bottle of champagne in the other. So  I was just sitting there, and then  the whole night flashed before my  eyes, and it struck me like a bullet  in the head-- I realized, finally,  and for the first time, that... I  wanted to kill somebody. So I figured  because I loved you so much, that'd  it'd be a good idea if I didn't see  you anymore. But now I'm different. He turns and points the gun at the front door and FIRES t shots through it, leaving two baseball-size holes in the  door. Martin bolts out of the room toward the back of the house Debi and Newberry run as fast as they can away from Marti Newberry opens the front door, preparing to rush out with Debi. They stop at what they see: NEWBERRY'S & DEBI'S P.O.V. As ASSASSIN lies on the porch, shot dead through the door Martin. IN one hand is a gun, in the other is a Fuller Br kit. Two men, GROCER and an ASSASSIN, clamber out of van, their guns rising up fast toward us. Debi pulls Newberry inside, slams the front door, and loc it. They dive away just before ten rounds hit the door fr outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin rushes toward the back door which is already openi A barrel comes through and FIRES at Martin. Martin pulls  back behind the refrigerator and returns FIRE. An ASSASSI comes through the door in a crouch and takes cover behind the cooking island. Martin, yelling back to Debi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in love with you. I know we can  make this work!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: rushes toward the island, grabbing an iron skillet off th range, and holds it up like a crossing-guard stop sign. H steps toward the hidden Assassin just as the Assassin ris SHOOTING. The skillet takes two rounds before Martin hamm the Assassin's head with it. Debi and Newberry arrive in kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LOW DUTCH
dialogues.text: Martin bashes the skillet into the Assassin's skull, whic is beyond our view. He rises spattered with blood and loo at Debi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was afraid to commit to a  relationship, but now I know I'm  ready to make it happen. Martin drops the skillet and grabs Newberry and Debi gent be the wrists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need time to change. He ushers them past the bludgeoned corpse and up the back stairs. He spins and FIRES twice back down the stairs at  another ASSASSIN coming up, blowing his arms off.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: He leads them quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not easy for me. I was raised  to close off, to control my  feelings... He takes them into a bedroom, and BLOWS AWAY, an ASSASSIN coming in through the window, emptying his auto. Martin p Debi and Newberry into an adjoining bathroom. He backs ou through the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock the door. They do. Martin starts away, but stops to get something  straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't raised in a loving  environment. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not an excuse. It's a  reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin corners the banister and springs half-way down the stairs, then hears the front door begin to open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My soul was empty-- Martin jams in another clip, and chambers a round. He see Grocer beginning to slip in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and it's up to me to fill it. Martin FIRES the twelve-round clip into the door until th slide locks back empty again. Grocer backs out fast. Mart hears a gun REPORT from upstairs and moves back toward it tossing the spent weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ASSASSIN slams his body against the bathroom door whil Debi and Newberry scream from within. Martin flies at him The Assassin wheels on Martin FIRING. Martin pivots out o the line of fire, still moving forward. He takes hold of  Assassin's neck and snaps it. Martin drops the corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. It's Martin The door begins  to open revealing Debi and Newberry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I do isn't moral, per  se, but if you could just look past  that, you'd see a man worth loving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't listen to him, he's a  professional. Martin stops short and cocks his head toward Grocer's muf voice coming from the vent. Grocer continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're breaking my heart down here,  Blank. I can't shoot through the  tears. Martin, incensed, bends down and takes the gun from the d man. He runs out of the bedroom, gun poised for a kamikaz firefight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner and McCullers are poised outside the front door,  about to enter the mix. McCullers peers through the windo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see Blank in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. For a second there I thought  we were in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: reaches the top of the front stairs to find Grocer headin up the stairs at him. They lift their guns at each other FIRE, when they hear...

dialogues.speaker: LARDNER AND MCCULLERS
dialogues.text: power through the front door, guns BLAZING at floor-level ala Butch and Sundance. Martin and Grocer, above, spin on them instinctively, and FIRE, killing them. Grocer dives off of the stairs and ro out of view.

dialogues.speaker: GROCER
dialogues.text: heads up the back stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: works his way toward Grocer, moving with stealth toward t kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: GROCER
dialogues.text: hears him and starts back down. Martin dives behind the cooking island just as Grocer com out of the stairwell blasting. They unload at each other Grocer runs a pattern across the kitchen, FIRING at Marti crouched, who BLASTS back. Grocer vaults himself through air toward a serving window from the kitchen to the dinin room, still firing.

dialogues.speaker: C.U.
dialogues.text: The last casing floats out of the chamber into the air, a the slide on the auto locks back-- empty.

dialogues.speaker: GROCER
dialogues.text: Flying through the air disappearing through the shuttered serving window, his flight carrying him past a television that sits on a lazy susan.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND GROCER
dialogues.text: Martin and Grocer sit on the floor, backs up against oppo side of the counter-- Martin in the kitchen and Grocer in the dining room. The hulking old television sits on the  counter above and between them. Martin looks up and spies the TELEVISION

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...How about I sell you two rounds  for a hundred grand a piece?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Martin takes out a checkbook, and tears one free. He wads into a loose ball and tosses it over the counter.

dialogues.speaker: BALLED CHECK
dialogues.text: sails over the television and comes down, bouncing off  Grocer's head and into his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go. I left it blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. Here they come. Grocer pulls two rounds from the clip of his semi-automat and pushes the clip back into the gun. Grocer arcs the TW BULLETS into the air.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: rises and springs at the television, gripping it. The TWO BULLETS sail past his head.

dialogues.speaker: GROCER
dialogues.text: begins to rise from his side of the counter, cocking his  gun.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: puts all his weight and motion behind the television. Mar and the television careen off of the counter toward Groce

dialogues.speaker: GROCER
dialogues.text: gets off one round before

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: flies onto Grocer, smashing the seventy-five pound televi over his Goddamn head. Martin sails past the collision,  landing on his back in the dining room. He rolls over to

dialogues.speaker: GROCER
dialogues.text: Body crumpled, neck is snapped, head encased in the shatt picture tube. He is dead.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: runs up the front stairs, retrieving the spent gun he  discarded earlier, and heads into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin opens the bathroom door. Inside, Debi sits on the  edge of the tub, her face in her hands. Newberry kneels w his arms around her. Martin takes this in, and walks back into the bedroom. Newberry stands and follows him out.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND NEWBERRY
dialogues.text: MARTIN a bloody, tattered mess, wipes off the gun and put it into Newberry's hand. Newberry, in total shock, grips Martin looks past Newberry. MARTIN'S P.O.V. Of Debi, head in hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi... will you marry me? Debi doesn't look up. After a moment, she reaches out, he still down, and closes the bathroom door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside is a Michigan autumn. Debi sits at her console,  bringing in the mike as she fades out of a tune...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is WRFN Radio Free Newberry  cause that's what it does. Bringing  you New Ones for the Nineties, a  fresh new format designed to pull  you out of what's come before, and  reel you into what's coming soon--

dialogues.speaker: THE PHONE CONSOLE
dialogues.text: lights up with an incoming cal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you what's coming soon for  me, or at least what I dreamed this  morning in that weird time just before  you actually wake up. But first this  commercial. Back after this... She pushes a couple of buttons, slaps a cartridge in a pl and answers the phone. We hear the commercial over the st monitor:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't miss the show of the season at  Bilkin Community Center! "Brigadoon!"  A musical for all ages! "Brigadoon,"  starring Carol Plummer, Thomas  Canchola, Bob Destephano, and Lee  Ordman!... Debi picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: RFN...
dialogues.text: Her face goes slack as she listens... not good, not bad.. Then she hangs up slowly. The commercial ends. A moment o dead air, then she snaps to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey out there... Okay... I'm going  to finish up that fantasy later.  First I'll give you an hour of nonstop  music... If I don't come back on  after that-- well, nevermind. Debi turns on a reel-to-reel, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi pulls up and gets out. She begins toward the door bu stops dead when she sees

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: sitting on the front steps. Debi moves slowly up the walk and sits next to him on the porch. They sit, gazing out over the grass and trees beyo After a while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will never work out. She turns to him, serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kill people. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no illusions about the future.  What is, is. We make choices. And we  become the sum total of our choices.  I can live with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other people can't. Martin looks at her earnestly... And smiles ever so sligh She does the same, and then just a little wider. He the s They turn back out to face the lawn, and they share a lau
